overview.name: Programme overview
overview.paragraph:
The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating economic impact, threatening the jobs and livelihoods of many South Africans – especially the most vulnerable. The pandemic has exacerbated South Africa’s pre-existing crises of poverty and unemployment. The Presidential Employment Stimulus recognises the urgency of this situation, using direct public investment to support public employment, job retention and livelihood support programmes, as part of the wider economic recovery process.  This provides direct support to participants and their families, but also acts as a stimulus in local economies, with spending mainly in township and rural economies. This provides a vital stimulus to small enterprise and the informal sector - trickling up into the wider economy from there.
This platform tracks the performance of the programmes that form part of the Presidential Employment Stimulus. It reflects work in progress, with the data updated monthly.

departments.name: Agriculture, Land Reform and Rural Development
departments.lead: Expanding support to farmers and protecting food value chains
departments.paragraph: The pandemic has illustrated the vulnerability of our food production and distribution systems. Although exempt from the strictest lockdown regulations, the sector faced severe challenges with disruptions to production and marketing experienced by many small-scale farmers. The Presidential Employment Stimulus is supporting subsistence farmers, through the provision of production input vouchers. Applications were done on a USSD platform, providing DALRRD with a geo-spatially referenced data-base of subsistence farmers for the first time. Agricultural graduates are being used to do on-site verification of applicants, collecting additional data that provides a basis for future support also.

implementation_details.detail: The department received over 178 000 applications through the USSD platform developed to administer the call for applications. Of these, 131 000 have been pre-approved and physical verification of applicants is underway, to ensure that farmer activity is as reported. The process of issuing vouchers to eligible verified applicants has also begun.

departments.name: Basic Education
departments.lead: School assistants strengthen the learning environment at schools
departments.paragraph: The Basic Education Employment Intervention (BEEI) of the DBE creates opportunities for a target of 300,000 young people, placed as school assistants at over 22,000 schools. This enables a high level of spatial equity, reaching communities everywhere. School assistants are selected by schools at the local level. There are two categories of assistants. For Education Assistant posts, matric is a requirement and graduates are prioritised. The Education Assistants support teachers in the classroom and assist with administration. For General Assistants, there is no minimum education qualification required. The General Assistants support maintenance and security at schools, as well as other tasks identified by the school. In addition, the stimulus supports teachers posts normally funded by School Governing Bodies at fee-paying schools, in a context in which parents were struggling to pay fees as a result of the economic impact of the pandemic. This placed these jobs at risk.

implementation_detail.detail: The department has placed close to 200 000 education assistants in schools across the country. These young people provide crucial support to teachers in the classroom and perform administrative tasks. Feedback from principals and teachers to date has been strongly positive, with the school assistants credited with supporting learning outcomes during a difficult time for all. Despite the challenges, and with the support of civil society organisations, DBE has also rolled out training of diverse kinds to the school assistants, with a focus on topics that enhance their ability to support curriculum outcomes - such as reading for meaning, maths literacy and ICT.

The department has placed more than the anticipated 100 000 general assistants in all schools across the country. The general assistants are supporting maintenance and security at schools and other basic needs. The period of school closures was used to good effect, with diverse maintenance and classroom upgrade activities undertaken.

This programme is protecting vulnerable teacher posts across the schooling system. Although initially targeted at quintile 4 and 5 schools, the support was targeted to all other schools in recognition of support required in poorer schools as well. This funding support has been undersubscribed and so where possible, provinces are using it to extend the school assistants programme.

departments.name: Co-operative government
departments.lead: Mainstreaming and improving labour-intensity in infrastructure delivery
departments.paragraph: In certain areas of infrastructure delivery, labour-intensive methods can enhance the job creation impact, while delivering the same quality of infrastructure outcomes. While there has long been policy support for labour-intensive methods, these are not always used in practice. Through the stimulus, the Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA) of DCOGTA is building the capacity of municipalities to utilise these methods. Fifteen municipalities have been targeted; others have asked to join the process. This component is only expected to deliver results against the employment target in the 2021/22 financial year, because of the contracting cycle for municipal infrastructure.

implementation_detail.detail: The Municipal Infrastructure Support Agency (MISA) has finalised the tender process and appointed a service provider to deliver the capacity development and roll-out the programme. Implementation has commenced.

departments.name: Environment, Forestry and Fisheries
departments.lead: Investing in the environment we live in
departments.paragraph: The work undertaken in environmental, forestry and fishery programmes will touch the length and breadth of the country, from coast to coast, including bushveld, grassland, fynbos, wetlands, mountains, water bodies, catchment areas  – and urban areas, too. The work undertaken affects the air we breathe, the water we drink, the energy we use and the food we eat, supporting a wealth of biodiversity resources and ecological systems essential to life on earth and to the future of the planet.

implementation_detail.programme_name: Cleaning and greening - war on waste with municipalities
implementation_detail.detail: Significant delays were experienced in the procurement processes required and implementation is behind schedule.

SANBI infrastructure maintenance is performing well.

departments.name: Public Works and Infrastructure
departments.lead: Graduate placements in the professional services
departments.paragraph: In addition to structural skills shortages that were experienced prior to the pandemic, the management of facilities and completion of infrastructure projects has been further impacted by restrictions on the movement of people and limitations placed on completing infrastructure projects during the lockdown. As the economy re-opens, additional capacity is required to address the backlog so that service provision can be restored. The Presidential Employment Stimulus is supporting graduate placements in a range of programmes linked to facilities management and infrastructure delivery mandate of the department.  An additional benefit is that students on the programme will obtain sufficient work experience to obtain their qualification thus helping to reduce the backlog that the TVET Colleges and University of Technologies are experiencing.

departments.name: Sports, Arts and Culture
departments.lead: Getting artists, cultural workers and the sporting sector on the road to recovery
departments.paragraph: Under lockdown, there has been no loud applause in jazz venues, no curtain calls for the dancers, no tourists in craft markets – and no victory laps for our sports people. No segment of the creative, cultural and sporting sectors has been untouched. The stimulus is supporting a range of public employment programmes and job retention programmes for the creative and sports sectors. It has also supported a stimulus to support the creative sector to return to work, through grants to the National Arts Council and the National Film and Video Foundation.

implementation_detail.detail: The lockdown restrictions and the fact that most facilities have been closed has led to low demand from National Federations and thus the set target will not be reached.

metrics.name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein

implementation_detail.programme_name: Banking with art, connecting Lives - National Museum Bloemfontein
implementation_detail.detail: The programme is progressing well. The approved visual artists are creating artworks for consideration by the Art Bank of South Africa as part of economic recovery.

metrics.name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory

implementation_detail.programme_name: Assistance with business growth strategies and marketing plans - South African Cultural Observatory
implementation_detail.detail: Following delays in obtaining approval, the National Treasury has granted the department permission to use South African Cultural Observatory (SACO) as an implementing agent for the programme. The department has issued a call to provinces to identify artists to be trained by appointed graduates. Although delayed, implementation is now in process.

metrics.name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres

implementation_detail.programme_name: Public Art, towards a people's culture - Community Arts Centres
implementation_detail.detail: Delays in implementation due to slow progress in signing the Memorandum of Agreement with implementing agents.

metrics.name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency

implementation_detail.programme_name: Audit of national museums - South African Heritage Resources Agency
implementation_detail.detail: The programme has appointed young people to conduct audits of memorials, monuments and statues around the country. It is progressing well and so far 417 of 676 recorded sites have been approved.

metrics.name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa

implementation_detail.programme_name: Digitisation of records - National Library of South Africa
implementation_detail.detail: The delays in the finalization of the MoA with the department delayed the project, especially procurement of key equipment and services. The programme has however appointed participants and begun prepatory work for the digitisation process.

Delays in the finalisation of the MOA with the department delayed procurement of equipment. The programme has recruited and appointed participants who have commenced work, however this is limited to preparatory work and other tasks as digitisation can only commence once the equipment is available.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support art and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in cultural and creative institutions - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The call for proposals for the job retention component of the stimulus was undersubscribed. Unallocated funds from job retention were reallocated to augment the funds available to support art and culture practitioners.

metrics.name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust

implementation_detail.programme_name: Job retention in sport sector - Sport Trust
implementation_detail.detail: The programme was oversubscribed and 65 organisations are receiving support to retain jobs in the sector. The largest component is support to the golf sector to retain and create jobs for caddies.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Arts Council
implementation_detail.detail: The National Arts Council's (NAC) allocated awards that exceeded the total available funds for the programme. In an attempt to remedy this, awards already made were withdrawn and grant amounts revised downwards. This caused disruption in the sector, in a context in which commitments had often already been made against the intital awards issued. The process also caused delays in payments. The NAC has instituted an investigation into the defects in the management and oversight of the allocations.

metrics.name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation

implementation_detail.programme_name: Support to art and culture practitioners - National Film and Video Foundation
implementation_detail.detail: The NFVF issued a call for proposals to the sector which was significantly oversubscribed. The NVFV has successfully completed the adjudication of these, issuing over 300 awards supporting projects that create work in the sector.

departments.name: Social Development
departments.lead: Income support to practitioners and to the implementation of Covid compliance measures
departments.paragraph: Livelihoods from the provision of Early Childhood Development services were severely disrupted by the pandemic, with providers facing challenges with re-opening. There are costs associated with doing so safely, plus many sites have faced a loss of income, with some parents unable to afford to pay fees as a result of losing their jobs. To support the sector back on its feet, the ECD Employment Stimulus Relief Fund (ECD –ESRF) is intended to benefit 108 833 workers. This comprises support to 83 333 ECD workers as well as top up payments to 25 500 existing ECD workers, to support Covid-19 compliance at ECD sites. Over 140 civil society organisations have assisted ECD centres to apply for this support.

implementation_detail.detail: The programme faced significant delays and challenges in the planning phase and will not be implemented.

dimensions.name: Jobs saved going to 18-35 year olds

implementation_detail.detail: Appointments and re-appointments have been finalised in several participating programmes and social workers have commenced work.

The department launched applications for the ECD Employment Stimulus Relief Fund (ECD –ESRF) in February. The support was oversubscribed and verification of programmes is currently underway. The department is working closely with its partners in the ECD sector to distribute income support for 108,833 workers in registered and unregistered ECD programmes.

departments.name: Science and Innovation
departments.lead: Supporting new graduates entering a hostile labour market
departments.paragraph: Given a constrained labour market, fewer opportunities have been available to graduates leaving institutions of higher learning over this period. The Department of Science and Innovation is delivering four programmes which will together employ 1,900 unemployed graduates. The HSRC is employing graduates as Health Promotion Agents at community level. The Enviro-Champs programme of the Duzi-Umngeni Conservation Trust is supporting water quality testing on the Umngeni River. The Water Research Council is placing graduates with host institutions to conduct water related projects and research while the CSIR has received support to expand its experiential learning programme.

implementation_detail.detail: The programme experienced administrative challenges in the planning phase which has led to delays. The recruitment of participants is currently under way and will be completed in two phases. These participants will be responsible for building social compacts to initiate behaviour change interventions at community level during the early stages of the Covid-19 pandemic

A delay in the transfer of funds from the department to the implementing agent led to a slow start. Also, additional partners had to be mobilised to fund the programme. Implementation is now on track, with people appointed as champions of the environment (Enviro-Champs) in their local community. Through a green livelihoods programme, people living adjacent to rivers are given the responsibility to adopt-a-stretch – cleaning, maintaining, greening, restoring, and undertaking citizen science monitoring on that section of the river.

Placement has commenced however, it was affected by university system closures which meant students could not register and provide proof as part of the application process. The appointed  Science, Engineering and Technology (SET) students will be supported to fulfil university pre-requisites for structured practical work exposure and training.

The programme experienced several challenges with securing hosts for the graduates which led to delays in the two-phased recruitment process. To date, the WRC has finalised appointments for phase 1 of the recruiment and these graduates are placed with various hosts. Phase 2 is currently underway.

departments.name: Trade, Industry and Competition
departments.lead: Piloting new models for re-shoring and expanding global business services
departments.paragraph: The Global Business Services sector has built from a low base to achieve an average year-on-year export revenue growth of at least 20%. This is as a result of an effective partnership between the dtic and the private sector.  The sector includes call centres and other digital technology services. It is one of few sectors that has been able to grow in the context of Covid-19. The Presidential Employment Stimulus recognised the opportunity to further boost growth in this sector, supporting additional incentives for a target of 8,000 jobs.

implementation_detail.detail: There has been good uptake of the incentives from the private sector and effective rollout by the dtic.

departments.name: Health
departments.lead: Primary Health Care is at the frontline of the battle against Covid-19
departments.paragraph: As the world responds to the COVID-19 pandemic, the critical role that  health workers play to enhance the resilience of the national health care system has been foregrounded. Community health workers have been on the frontline of active case-finding through screening and contact tracing. In some instances, these workers have been called upon to deliver these services without adequate support and supervision.  Similarly, nursing staff without public facilities have provided much needed care services in the most vulnerable communities. The stimulus support to the sector seeks to augment this capacity and address gaps through the recruitment of additional community health workers and outreach team leaders for supervision. Moreover, additional enrolled and auxillary nurses are targeted to increase capacity in public health facilities.

implementation_detail.detail: The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes and the programme will not be implemented.
The department faced severe constraints related to rollout in the timeframes and the programme will not be implemented.

The programme was able to commence with recruitment immediately by relying on existing databases of unemployed health professionals. The department has exceeded its target to date. Appointed nurses are providing a range of primary health care services in public facilities and are playing a central role in the roll-out of the COVID-19 vaccination programme.

The programme was able to commence with recruitment immediately by relying on existing databases of unemployed health professionals. The department has exceeded its target to date. Appointed auxiliary nurses are supporting various services in public health facilities as part of the response to COVID-19.

departments.name: Transport
departments.lead: Improving access to services and opportunities for people in rural areas
departments.paragraph: Rural roads play a vital role in connecting rural communities to services such as health and education, as well as providing access to markets and economic opportunities. However, rural roads infrastructure remains poor in many areas of South Africa. Provinces are receiving support to scale up rural roads maintenance.

implementation_detail.detail: The provinicial departments faced procurement delays in the planning phase and implementation was also affected by cyclone Eloise. These challenges are still ongoing in some provinces, however, several projects have commenced and participants have been appointed, with maintenance of rural roads underway in most provinces.
